title: MVC Concept On Laravel
excerpt: Understand the Model-View-Controller (MVC) design pattern and how it's applied in the Laravel framework.
content:
Introduction to MVC

The Model-View-Controller (MVC) is an architectural pattern widely used in web development. It separates an application into three interconnected parts.

Model

The Model represents the application's data structure and business logic. In Laravel, Models typically interact with the database.

namespace App\Models;

use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Factories\HasFactory;
use Illuminate\Database\Eloquent\Model;

class Post extends Model
{
    use HasFactory;

    protected $fillable = ['title', 'body'];
}

View

The View is the user interface. In Laravel, Views are typically Blade templates that render HTML and display data.

<!-- resources/views/posts/show.blade.php -->

<h1>{{ $post->title }}</h1>
<p>{{ $post->body }}</p>

Controller

The Controller acts as an intermediary between the Model and the View. It handles user input, interacts with the Model, and selects the appropriate View to render.

namespace App\Http\Controllers;

use App\Models\Post;
use Illuminate\Http\Request;

class PostController extends Controller
{
    public function show(Post $post)
    {
        return view('posts.show', ['post' => $post]);
    }
}

How MVC Works in Laravel

When a user makes a request, the router directs it to the appropriate Controller. The Controller interacts with the Model to fetch or manipulate data, and then passes that data to the chosen View, which renders the response sent back to the user.

This separation of concerns makes the application more organized, maintainable, and scalable.
